title: The sound the universe makes - Janna Levin

multiple-choice.question: Factual Question

options.label: A
options.text: The universe is silent and does not make any sounds.

options.label: B
options.text: The universe is not silent and makes sounds that can be detected.

options.label: C
options.text: The universe is silent, but space itself can make sounds.

options.label: D
options.text: The universe is not a silent movie, but it does not make any sounds.

multiple-choice.question: Conceptual Question

options.label: A
options.text: Black holes are dark objects that do not interact with the environment.

options.label: B
options.text: Black holes are dark objects that destroy stars and churn up debris in their surroundings.

options.label: C
options.text: Black holes are dark objects that do not affect the environment.

options.label: D
options.text: Black holes are not dark objects, but they are visible in the night sky.

multiple-choice.question: Application Question

options.label: A
options.text: If the sun were to collapse into a black hole, the Earth would be destroyed instantly.

options.label: B
options.text: If the sun were to collapse into a black hole, the Earth would be in a stable orbit around the black hole.

options.label: C
options.text: If the sun were to collapse into a black hole, the Earth would be unaffected.

options.label: D
options.text: If the sun were to collapse into a black hole, the Earth would be pulled into the black hole immediately.

multiple-choice.question: Analytical Question

options.label: A
options.text: The sound of black holes is a constant, steady tone.

options.label: B
options.text: The sound of black holes is a series of distinct, ringing tones.

options.label: C
options.text: The sound of black holes is a chaotic, cacophonous noise.

options.label: D
options.text: The sound of black holes is a silent, inaudible noise.

multiple-choice.question: Factual Question

options.label: A
options.text: The LIGO experiment is designed to detect deviations in the squeezing and stretching of space at a distance of 1 km.

options.label: B
options.text: The LIGO experiment is designed to detect deviations in the squeezing and stretching of space at a distance of 4 km.

options.label: C
options.text: The LIGO experiment is designed to detect deviations in the squeezing and stretching of space at a distance of 1 nucleus of an atom.

options.label: D
options.text: The LIGO experiment is designed to detect deviations in the squeezing and stretching of space at a distance of 4 km.

multiple-choice.question: Conceptual Question

options.label: A
options.text: The Big Bang was a singular event that occurred in our universe.

options.label: B
options.text: The Big Bang was a singular event that occurred in the Multiverse.

options.label: C
options.text: The Big Bang was a series of events that occurred in our universe.

options.label: D
options.text: The Big Bang was a series of events that occurred in the Multiverse.

multiple-choice.question: Application Question

options.label: A
options.text: If we were to detect the sound of the Big Bang, it would be a clear, distinct tone.

options.label: B
options.text: If we were to detect the sound of the Big Bang, it would be a chaotic, cacophonous noise.

options.label: C
options.text: If we were to detect the sound of the Big Bang, it would be a silent, inaudible noise.

options.label: D
options.text: If we were to detect the sound of the Big Bang, it would be a series of distinct, ringing tones.

multiple-choice.question: Analytical Question

options.label: A
options.text: The concept of the Multiverse is a scientific theory that has been proven.

options.label: B
options.text: The concept of the Multiverse is a scientific theory that is still being researched.

options.label: C
options.text: The concept of the Multiverse is a scientific theory that is widely accepted.

options.label: D
options.text: The concept of the Multiverse is a scientific theory that is not supported by evidence.

multiple-choice.question: Factual Question

options.label: A
options.text: The Lisa mission is designed to detect super massive black holes in the universe.

options.label: B
options.text: The Lisa mission is designed to detect deviations in the squeezing and stretching of space.

options.label: C
options.text: The Lisa mission is designed to detect the sound of black holes in the universe.

options.label: D
options.text: The Lisa mission is designed to detect the sound of the Big Bang in the universe.

multiple-choice.question: Conceptual Question

options.label: A
options.text: The universe is a single, isolated event that occurred in the past.

options.label: B
options.text: The universe is a part of a larger Multiverse that contains multiple branches and events.

options.label: C
options.text: The universe is a static, unchanging entity that has always existed.

options.label: D
options.text: The universe is a dynamic, evolving entity that is still changing today.

title: What makes us feel good about our work? - Dan Ariely

options.label: C
options.text: People work solely for the purpose of achieving happiness in the moment.

options.label: D
options.text: People work solely for the purpose of achieving recognition and respect.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between the "meaningful condition" and "Sisyphic" conditions in the Lego experiment?

options.label: A
options.text: The meaningful condition involved building Legos for a fixed amount of money, while the Sisyphic condition involved building Legos for a variable amount of money.

options.label: B
options.text: The meaningful condition involved building Legos for a variable amount of money, while the Sisyphic condition involved building Legos for a fixed amount of money.

options.label: C
options.text: The meaningful condition involved building Legos for a fixed amount of money, while the Sisyphic condition involved building Legos for a fixed amount of money but with the added twist of destroying the previous Lego.

options.label: D
options.text: The meaningful condition involved building Legos for a variable amount of money, while the Sisyphic condition involved building Legos for a variable amount of money but with the added twist of destroying the previous Lego.

options.label: B
options.text: The meaningful condition resulted in 11 Bionicles being built, while the Sisyphic condition resulted in 7 Bionicles being built.

options.label: C
options.text: The meaningful condition resulted in 7 Bionicles being built, while the Sisyphic condition resulted in 11 Bionicles being built.

options.label: D
options.text: The meaningful condition resulted in 10 Bionicles being built, while the Sisyphic condition resulted in 5 Bionicles being built.

options.text: There was a positive correlation between love of Legos and the number of Bionicles built.

options.label: C
options.text: There was no correlation between love of Legos and the number of Bionicles built.

options.label: D
options.text: The correlation was not measured in the meaningful condition.

options.text: The knowledge economy is more focused on meaning, while the Industrial Revolution is more focused on efficiency.

title: Mysteries of vernacular: Odd - Jessica Oreck and Rachael Teel

multiple-choice.question: What is the origin of the word "odd" in the context of mathematics?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.text: It referred to a shape with all sides equal.

options.label: D

options.label: C

title: Mysteries of vernacular: Yankee - Jessica Oreck and Rachael Teel

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary origin of the word "Yankee"?

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: From a term of honor to a neutral term

title: Mysteries of vernacular: Lady - Jessica Oreck and Rachael Teel

multiple-choice.question: What is the origin of the word "lady"?

options.label: A
options.text: From the Old English word "hlaf", referring to refer to a loaf of bread

options.label: B
options.text: From the Old English word "hlafdige", which means loaf maid

options.label: C

options.text: A female head of the household, or the kneader of bread
